The situation feels very volatile, with Buhari's mysterious health state, Boho Haram (a lesser menace than a couple of years ago, but nonetheless still present) and increasing ethnic tensions. difficult to predict.

920 civilians have been killed intentionally so far during 2017. 288 by Boko Haram, 192 by the Fulani militias. I don't expect that any group will kill >1.000 civilians intentionally during this period. Violence in Nigeria for me is somewhat unpredictable though, so I'll go with 12%.
The activities of Boko. However, the Nigerian army has had some major successes against Boko but the group is still active in Nigeria and other neighbouring countries.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Systematic killing of civilians reaching over 1,000 (as defined above) is unlikely for either the government or Boko Haram. I'd be interested to know if I'm missing some key information that has others forecasting higher.

Systematic killings of civilians in mass quantities requires the situation to already be pretty bleak, with no real hope of survival by the civilians (otherwise it would create a resistance movement) and no real belief by any group (government or Boko Haram) of the need to concern themselves with maintaining some semblance of civilian tolerance, let alone support.
Boko Haram is quite capable of this. If the government makes inroads against Boko Haram, the latter could lead such a campaign instantly
